Stay safe and hug your children tight. We love you!

The Oregon Department of Education has released an update to guidance for reopening in September: ODE Ready Schools, Safe Learners Version 2.7.2 - Updated July 22, 2020. The safety and well-being of our students, families, and staff is at the forefront of our planning, and we are planning to ensure that each child feels welcome, safe, and successful, and each child knows they belong and are valued.

In terms of what school might look like...here is an example of a classroom with all extra furniture removed and desks spaced according to requirements.

post_text: Juneteenth is a day of recognition and celebration. On June 19th, 1865, federal troops arrived in Galveston, Texas to announce that the Civil War had ended and ensure that all enslaved people were freed. Although it was two and a half years after the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation, Juneteenth is a symbolic date commemorating African-American freedom.

HMK Company is at Talent Middle School.
June 18 at 9:16 AM · Talent, OR ·

Talent Middle School Mechanical Upgrade

The work continues at TMS on the Mechanical Upgrades. The new high efficiency boilers and chiller are now in place and the roof is getting prepared for the new units by installing the curbs. The design team was able to continue the using the mechanical cabinets, with upgraded motors, fans, coils, etc. and adding terminal units. These upgrades will continue the life of the systems and provide independent temperature control in each of the classrooms. Additionally, the school had a combination of pneumatic and aging digital controls. This project will replace all of the controls, allowing the district to manage energy usage, Co2 levels, outside air and nightly air flushes.

In addition to the Mechanical upgrades, the fire alarm system is being upgraded to provide a safer environment for students and staff.

For the 2020-21 school year, each school will work under the direction of the school district to develop an Operational Blueprint for Reentry that meets the requirements outlined in the guidance. Before the beginning of the school year, our school board will review each school’s plan and make it available to the community on our website.

We wish you all a safe, healthy summer and can't wait to see you in the fall.

In honor of our students and the challenges we are facing in the communities we serve, the lights at Phoenix High School's Jack Woodward Stadium will be turned on every Friday night at 8:20 pm. This weekly event will begin this Friday, April 10 and continue until at least June 12.

"We want all of our students in the Phoenix-Talent School District to know how important they are to us and that we care for each and every one of them," Phoenix-Talent District Athletic Director Dave Ehrhardt said.

The lights will come on Friday nights at 20:20 military time, in honor of our Class of 2020 seniors, and will light up the stadium for one minute of each school day lost during this pandemic.

The weekly lighting of the stadium at PHS will start less than two days after the State of Oregon announced that schools would not re-open for the remainder of the school year. Coinciding with that announcement, the OSAA announced that all remaining spring activities and state championships are also canceled.

March 18, 2020
Dear Families,
I would like to start by sharing that we appreciate and value each and everyone of you. We are experiencing unprecedented times and we know there is uncertainty on what our education system will look like in the coming weeks. I want to assure you, Phoenix-Talent Schools will have a plan for ALL students to access education as outlined in the Governor's Executive Order.
We have online resources for students/families on our website. These resources include district adopted curriculum and supplemental resources. In addition, we will have our staff contacting families on March 30th to set up individualized instruction and assess student/family needs.
We look forward to partnering with you during these difficult times. We understand there are specific concerns for high school seniors and their families, please know we are prioritizing our support in helping students meet graduation requirements.
Please feel free to email questions to askPTS@phoenix.k12.or.us (English and Spanish).
Thank you,
Brent Barry, Superintendent

The Rogue Valley YMCA may have an answer for some parents who need to be at work and are struggling to find childcare amid the COVID-19 outbreak, especially first responders who need to be out working during the pandemic.

The Rogue Valley YMCA announced an “Emergency Child Care Plan” that will start Monday. As part of the plan, the YMCA is suspending their usual after school and day camp program until schools re-open. The resources that were freed up will now go toward taking care of kids whose parents are medical and healthcare workers, first responders, and vulnerable populations.

Emergency child care sites include Phoenix Elementary and Orchard Hill Elementary Schools.

John Cornet‎Track & Field at Phoenix HS, Ore.
May 19, 2019 at 12:35 AM ·

I am pleased to share that Sienna Bauer is a newly minted STATE CHAMPION!
At the Oregon State Championships in Gresham, she ran the 100m High Hurdles in a time of 14.96a. Just how impressive is her time? Consider this: in the entire history of the 4A-school size (dating back to 1978, when girls started to run the current metric distance and 33” hurdle height), Sienna’s time is the eighth fastest ever!
In so doing, Sienna joins a small sorority of prior Phoenix girls State Champions: Maryl Barker (Mile, 880y), Kathy Pete (Discus), Jacqueline Huxtable (100m), Sandy Bean (Javelin), Dani Jantzer (800m, 1500m), Heather Sullivan (1500m), Emma Amundsen (3000m), and the 4x400m Relays of 2015 and 2016.
She is the first State Champion in this event for Phoenix. The other Phoenix girls who have placed at State in the High Hurdles are Renae Perisho (3rd,4th), Norma Pyle (2nd,3rd,4th), Debbie Jacobson (6th) and Kat Cox (8th). Sienna and Norma are the only three-time Phoenix placers in this event.

Southern Oregon Sparrow Clubs
October 5, 2018 at 10:03 AM ·

I wanted to share a very precious moment with everyone. Liam was adopted as the new Sparrow to his very own school today. He attends kindergarten at Orchard Hill Elementary.

Every child desires to be accepted and embraced by their peers. It’s not always easy to feel like you fit in, and being a 5-year-old “big kindergarten kiddo” can be scary. Then you add medical challenges to that, and it can all be very overwhelming. One might wonder, “how are people going to treat me.”
Well, today was a BIG POWERFUL moment for this sweet boy Liam. His peers heard his story, had a glimpse into his medical journey, and their reactions brought Liam to tears. Tears of complete joy, feelings of acceptance, and reassurance that the entire student body was a friend to this little boy.
Students were cheering, some crying, and they were so happy to embrace Liam.

Liam walked over to me, tears streaming down his face, hugged me, and whispered in my ears...”this was a good idea!!”

The power of love and what being cared for can do for the human soul! Liam and his family were flooded by that power today!!
